types.name: AbsoluteCmd
types.docstring: `AbsoluteCmd` represents a supported absolute SVG command.
types.signature:
pub(all) enum AbsoluteCmd {
  M
  L
  C
  Q
  Z
}

types.name: Anchor
types.docstring:
Anchor represents where to place the origin (0,0) of the glyph relative
 to its minimum bounding box.
types.signature:
pub(all) enum Anchor {
  Unchanged
  TopLeft
  TopCenter
  TopRight
  CenterLeft
  Center
  CenterRight
  BaselineLeft
  BaselineCenter
  BaselineRight
  BottomLeft
  BottomCenter
  BottomRight
  RatioXY(Double, Double)
}

types.name: Cmd
types.docstring: `Cmd` represents an SVG command along with its parameters.

types.name: Font
types.signature: pub(all) struct Font { id : String horiz_adv_x : Double units_per_em : Double ascent : Double descent : Double glyphs : Map[String, Glyph] }

methods.name: gen_path
methods.docstring:
`gen_path` "renders" the provided text string into an SVG path
 using the provided font information. It performs the necessary
 path translations in order to combine the individual glyphs into
 a "super glyph" that can be rendered as a whole.

 Note that `gen_path` operates on the string as a left-justified whole
 and anchors the entire path relative to `anchor` accordingly.

 If you want multiple lines centered horizontally, use `gen_paths` instead.

 Note that the SVG standard states that positive-Y is "down" with origin
 coordinates in the upper-left, however, all SVG fonts appear to have their
 origin in the lower left with positive-Y moving "up". This package
 attempts to convert the SVG paths such that the font is equally readable
 in both the "y_up=false" SVG canvas environment or in a 3D "y_up=true"
 rendering environment.
methods.signature: fn Font::gen_path(self : Font, text : String, anchor~ : Anchor = .., y_up~ : Bool = ..) -> Glyph!FontError

methods.name: gen_paths
methods.docstring:
`gen_paths` handles multiple strings independently so that they
 can be aligned and distributed more flexibly.
methods.signature: fn Font::gen_paths(self : Font, lines : Array[String], anchor~ : Anchor = .., y_up~ : Bool = ..) -> Array[Glyph]!FontError

types.name: GerberLP
types.docstring: `GerberLP` represents whether a subpath is `Dark` or `Clear`.

types.name: Glyph
types.docstring:
`Glyph` represents a single glyph within each `Font` and also represents
 multiple glyphs combined together (for example after using `Font.gen_path`
 and switching back and forth between `Glyphs` which are optimized for storage,
 and `Paths` which are optimized for processing).
types.signature:
pub(all) struct Glyph {
  char : String
  horiz_adv_x : Double
  gerber_lp : String
  d : String
  xmin : Double
  ymin : Double
  xmax : Double
  ymax : Double
}

types.name: ParamPair
types.docstring: `ParamPair` represents an X,Y absolute coordinate pair of parameters.

types.name: Params
types.docstring: `Params` represents the parameters to an SVG command.

types.name: Path
types.docstring:
A `Path` is identical to a `Glyph` but has been optimized internally
 for further manipulation, whereas a `Glyph` is optimized for compact
 storage of font data within all the font packages.
 A `Path` can be converted to a `Glpyh` and vice versa.
types.signature: pub(all) struct Path { char : String cmds : Array[PathCmd] xmin : Double ymin : Double xmax : Double ymax : Double }

methods.name: clone
methods.docstring: `clone` makes a deep copy of a Path.

methods.name: from_glyph
methods.docstring:
`from_glyph` returns a `Path` from a `Glyph`, optionally processing
 every `Cmd` with a processing function.
 Note that apart from `path_cmd_fn`, `from_glyph` makes no attempt to process the
 invidual glyphs and simply transforms the representation.

methods.name: to_glyph
methods.docstring:
`to_glyph` returns a "super" `Glyph` from a `Path`, optionally processing
 every `PathCmd` with a processing function.
 Note that apart from `path_cmd_fn`, `to_glyph` makes no attempt to process the
 invidual glyphs and simply transforms the representation.

types.name: PathCmd
types.docstring: `Cmd` represents an individual absolute SVG command.

methods.name: bbox
methods.docstring: `bbox` returns the minimum bounding box of a PathCmd.

methods.name: clone
methods.docstring: `clone` makes a deep copy of a PatchCmd.

types.name: PathCmdFn
types.docstring:
`PathCmdFn` represents a function that processes or transforms individual commands.
 The first argument is the index within the command.

types.name: Point

methods.name: is_in
methods.docstring: is_in reports whether p is in r.

methods.name: op_equal
methods.docstring: op_equal reports whether p and q are equal.

methods.name: to_string
methods.docstring: to_string returns a string representation of p like "(3,4)".

types.name: Rectangle
types.docstring:
A Rectangle contains the points with Min.X <= X < Max.X, Min.Y <= Y < Max.Y.
 It is well-formed if Min.X <= Max.X and likewise for Y. Points are always
 well-formed. A rectangle's methods always return well-formed outputs for
 well-formed inputs.

 A Rectangle is also an [Image] whose bounds are the rectangle itself. At
 returns color.Opaque for points in the rectangle and color.Transparent
 otherwise.

methods.name: add
methods.docstring: add returns the rectangle r translated by p.

methods.name: bounds
methods.docstring: `bounds` returns the tuple `(xmin, ymin, xmax, ymax)`.

methods.name: canon
methods.docstring:
canon returns the canonical version of r. The returned rectangle has minimum
 and maximum coordinates swapped if necessary so that it is well-formed.

methods.name: clone
methods.docstring: `clone` makes a copy of the provided rectangle without changing it.

methods.name: empty
methods.docstring: empty reports whether the rectangle contains no points.

methods.name: extend
methods.docstring: `extend` extends the current rectangle to include the provided point.

methods.name: inset
methods.docstring:
inset returns the rectangle r inset by n, which may be negative. If either
 of r's dimensions is less than 2*n then an empty rectangle near the center
 of r will be returned.

methods.name: intersect
methods.docstring:
intersect returns the largest rectangle contained by both r and s. If the
 two rectangles do not overlap then the zero rectangle will be returned.

methods.name: is_in
methods.docstring: is_in reports whether every point in r is in s.

methods.name: new
methods.docstring: Rectangle::new returns an empty (all zeros) rectangle.

methods.name: op_equal
methods.docstring:
op_equal reports whether r and s contain the same set of points. All empty
 rectangles are considered equal.

methods.name: overlaps
methods.docstring: overlaps reports whether r and s have a non-empty intersection.

methods.name: size
methods.docstring: size returns r's width and height.

methods.name: sub
methods.docstring: sub returns the rectangle r translated by -p.

methods.name: to_string
methods.docstring: to_string returns a string representation of r like "(3,4)-(6,5)".

methods.name: union
methods.docstring: union returns the smallest rectangle that contains both r and s.

values.name: add
values.docstring: add returns the rectangle r translated by p.

values.name: bbox
values.docstring: `bbox` returns the minimum bounding box of a PathCmd.

values.name: bounds
values.docstring: `bounds` returns the tuple `(xmin, ymin, xmax, ymax)`.

values.name: canon
values.docstring:
canon returns the canonical version of r. The returned rectangle has minimum
 and maximum coordinates swapped if necessary so that it is well-formed.

values.name: clone
values.docstring: `clone` makes a copy of the provided rectangle without changing it.

values.name: div
values.docstring: div returns the vector p/k.
values.signature: fn div(self : Point, k : Double) -> Point

values.name: dx
values.docstring: dx returns r's width.

values.name: dy
values.docstring: dy returns r's height.

values.name: empty
values.docstring: empty reports whether the rectangle contains no points.

values.name: extend
values.docstring: `extend` extends the current rectangle to include the provided point.

values.name: gen_path
values.docstring:
`gen_path` "renders" the provided text string into an SVG path
 using the provided font information. It performs the necessary
 path translations in order to combine the individual glyphs into
 a "super glyph" that can be rendered as a whole.

 Note that `gen_path` operates on the string as a left-justified whole
 and anchors the entire path relative to `anchor` accordingly.

 If you want multiple lines centered horizontally, use `gen_paths` instead.

 Note that the SVG standard states that positive-Y is "down" with origin
 coordinates in the upper-left, however, all SVG fonts appear to have their
 origin in the lower left with positive-Y moving "up". This package
 attempts to convert the SVG paths such that the font is equally readable
 in both the "y_up=false" SVG canvas environment or in a 3D "y_up=true"
 rendering environment.
values.signature: fn gen_path(self : Font, text : String, anchor~ : Anchor = .., y_up~ : Bool = ..) -> Glyph!FontError

values.name: gen_paths
values.docstring:
`gen_paths` handles multiple strings independently so that they
 can be aligned and distributed more flexibly.
values.signature: fn gen_paths(self : Font, lines : Array[String], anchor~ : Anchor = .., y_up~ : Bool = ..) -> Array[Glyph]!FontError

values.name: glyph_bbox
values.docstring:
`glyph_bbox` returns the conservative bounding box of a Glyph path.
 It only supports the absolute SVG commands: M, L, C, Q, Z.

 Note that this function does _NOT_ fully analyze the Cubic or Quadratic
 Bzier curves to determine their exact bounding boxes, but instead
 takes a naive and concervative approach by encapsulating the bounds
 of all control points in addition to curve anchor points which may result
 in returning a much larger bounding box than is actually needed to fully
 contain the glyph.

values.name: inset
values.docstring:
inset returns the rectangle r inset by n, which may be negative. If either
 of r's dimensions is less than 2*n then an empty rectangle near the center
 of r will be returned.

values.name: intersect
values.docstring:
intersect returns the largest rectangle contained by both r and s. If the
 two rectangles do not overlap then the zero rectangle will be returned.

values.name: is_in
values.docstring: is_in reports whether p is in r.

values.name: mul
values.docstring: mul returns the vector p*k.
values.signature: fn mul(self : Point, k : Double) -> Point

values.name: op_add
values.docstring: op_add (+) returns the vector p+q.
values.signature: fn op_add(self : Point, q : Point) -> Point

values.name: op_equal
values.docstring: op_equal reports whether p and q are equal.
values.signature: fn op_equal(self : Point, q : Point) -> Bool

values.name: op_sub
values.docstring: op_sub (-) returns the vector p-q.
values.signature: fn op_sub(self : Point, q : Point) -> Point

values.name: overlaps
values.docstring: overlaps reports whether r and s have a non-empty intersection.

values.name: pt
values.docstring: pt is shorthand for [Point]{X, Y}.
values.signature: fn pt(x : Double, y : Double) -> Point

values.name: rect
values.docstring:
rect is shorthand for Rectangle::{min: pt(x0, y0), max: pt(x1, y1)}. The returned
 rectangle has minimum and maximum coordinates swapped if necessary so that
 it is well-formed.
values.signature: fn rect(x0 : Double, y0 : Double, x1 : Double, y1 : Double) -> Rectangle

values.name: size
values.docstring: size returns r's width and height.

values.name: sub
values.docstring: sub returns the rectangle r translated by -p.

values.name: to_glyph
values.docstring:
`to_glyph` returns a "super" `Glyph` from a `Path`, optionally processing
 every `PathCmd` with a processing function.
 Note that apart from `path_cmd_fn`, `to_glyph` makes no attempt to process the
 invidual glyphs and simply transforms the representation.

values.name: to_string
values.docstring: to_string returns a string representation of p like "(3,4)".

values.name: translate_path
values.docstring:
`translate_path` translates (moves) an SVG path by the provided offsets.
 If `invert_y` is true, all `y` values are scaled by -1.
values.signature: fn translate_path(d : String, x : Double, y : Double, invert_y~ : Bool = ..) -> String!FontError

values.name: union
values.docstring: union returns the smallest rectangle that contains both r and s.
